newsitem.title: NORWAY: Analyst sees good benefits from Christiania merger.
newsitem.headline: Analyst sees good benefits from Christiania merger.

text.p: A merger between Norway's second largest bank, Christiania Bank og Kreditkasse ASA, and the country's biggest insurance group Storebrand ASA could lead to a rise of 15 to 25 percent in pre-tax profit by 2000 or 2001, an insurance analyst said on Wednesday.
But the merger had left Norway's leading commercial bank Den norske Bank ASA in a strategically difficult position.
"The merger is very exciting in terms of benefits both on the costs and revenues side," Nils Ringdal at Dresdner Kelinwort Benson in London told Reuters.
"We see benefits of between 15 to 25 percent in terms of increased pre-tax profits in a few years say in 2000 or 2001."
Consolidation has long been expected in Norway's overcrowded banking sector, and some analysts had proposed a joining of forces between DnB and Christiania Bank.

DnB took over the country's second largest life insurer Vital Forsikring in January, 1996, and entered into a bidding war on March 21 this year with Fokus Bank ASA for niche mortgage lender Bolig og Naeringsbanken (BNbank).
Ringdal said a merger between DnB and Christiania would have provided even greater synergy benefits.

"Merger benfits would probably have been higher between DnB and Christiania. It's a good solution for shareholders of Christiania, but it's probably not the best one. It's definitely good for Storebrand," he said.
"DnB is now in a strategic dilemma after today's announcement. I can't see how they can respond to this, they are out of options in the Norwegian market."
